choices.text: Stop MDT give thalidomide
Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids
Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

 

The situation described, where pre-existing lesions worsen during multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, indicates a type 1 lepra reaction. In managing this condition, the recommended approach would be to continue MDT while initiating systemic steroid treatment.

 

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are marked by inflammation of existing skin lesions, leading to symptoms such as edema, redness, and pain. While ulcers are uncommon, the development of new lesions is exceptionally rare. Additionally, acute neuritis may occur, presenting with tenderness and impairment of both motor and sensory functions.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued. NSAIDs and oral steroids can be added to treat pain.
  • Thalidomide is considered the gold standard for treating severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum. However, it is not the Drug of Choice due to its high cost and potential for adverse drug reactions. In type II lepra reactions, patients may experience systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of new skin lesions.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions:

 

(ENL = Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT give thalidomide

  • Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug that may be used in certain conditions, like leprosy and its complications.
  • However, stopping MDT is not recommended as it is crucial to continue the treatment of the primary disease. Thalidomide is not used as treatment for Type 1 lepra reaction in leprosy.

 

Option B. Continue MDT, start thalidomide –

While MDT should be continued, thalidomide is not typically used for nerve complications. It's used primarily for severe or recurrent erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) Type 2 Lepra reaction, which is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.

 

Option C. Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids –

  • Stopping MDT is not advised as the antibiotics in MDT are essential for treating the bacterial infection causing the disease.
  • The MDT should be continued to prevent the development of drug resistance and to adequately treat the underlying infection.

 

Option D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids -

  • This is the correct management for a leprosy patient with nerve damage, which is likely due to an immune reaction called a leprosy reaction. Systemic corticosteroids are used to control the inflammation and prevent further nerve damage.
  • MDT should be continued to treat the underlying infection.
  • The reason for selecting option D is that systemic corticosteroids are effective in treating acute nerve inflammation and can prevent further damage while continuing MDT ensures that the infection is adequately treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy, the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

questions.text: Fructosamine (which is used for assessing long term glycemic control in a person with hemolysis) is a glycated product of: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

Fructosamine is a compound formed when glucose binds to serum albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood. This glycated product provides an indicator of long-term glycemic control because it reflects the average blood glucose levels over the previous 2 to 3 weeks. Since it is primarily formed from the glycation of albumin, option d (Albumin) is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycosaminoglycan refers to a different type of compound, glycosaminoglycans, which are long, linear polysaccharides found in connective tissues.

 

Option B. Urea is a waste product removed by the kidneys and is not involved in fructosamine formation.

 

Option C. Fructose is a sugar but is not directly related to the formation of fructosamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose can be attached to proteins, albumin, and also to RBCs forming HbA1c. Fructosamine is term used for all the glycated proteins including glycated albumin.

 

 

 

In hemolysis patient, HbA1c analysis cannot be done because it will be falsely decreased due to damage to RBCs and loss of hemoglobin. So, fructosamine determination is used for these patients.

questions.text: The primary lymphoid organ is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymus

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature. The primary lymphoid organs are where lymphocytes (B cells and T cells) are produced and mature. The thymus specifically is the site of T cell maturation, a crucial process for the development of the immune system.

 

The bone marrow is another primary lymphoid organ, where B cells mature.

 

Secondary lymphoid organs, in contrast, are sites where mature lymphocytes become activated in response to antigens. These include the lymph nodes, spleen, Peyer’s patches, and tonsils.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver is not considered a lymphoid organ. It plays a role in various metabolic processes, detoxification, and protein synthesis, but it is not involved in the direct maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Lymph node: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. They are involved in filtering lymph and providing a site for the interaction of lymphocytes with antigens, which helps initiate the immune response.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is also a secondary lymphoid organ. It filters blood, removes old red blood cells, and helps in the immune response by facilitating the interaction between lymphocytes and antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It plays a critical role in the development of the immune system.

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles on the tympanic membrane and in the external auditory meatus, accompanied by features of facial nerve palsy. What is the diagnosis and which site is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

 

Clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay hunt syndrome (aka herpes zoster oticus).

 

Herpes Zoster Oticus (Ramsay–Hunt Syndrome) - It is a viral infection (herpes zoster virus) involving geniculate ganglion of facial nerve. It is characterized by appearance of vesicles on the tympanic membrane, deep meatus, concha and retro auricular sulcus.

 

It appears as a rash of small tense blisters with surrounding erythema, preceded by pain in the ears for several days

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome and Basal Ganglion: Incorrect because Ramsay Hunt syndrome affects the geniculate ganglion, not the basal ganglion.

 

Option C. & D. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by a triad of recurrent facial nerve paralysis, swelling of the lips (cheilitis granulomatosa), and a fissured tongue. It does not involve vesicular eruptions and primarily affects the facial appearance and function without vesicular rash. Paralysis may be recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a reactivation of herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a characteristic vesicular eruption on the ear and facial nerve palsy. Early recognition and treatment are vital to prevent complications and improve recovery.

questions.text: Identify the drug used to treat the condition shown below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anti-tubercular therapy

 

  • The image showing a plaque with one margin extending & other margin healing with scarring (Asymmetrical lesion), this favors to the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris, which is treated using anti-tubercular drugs.
  • It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in India.
  • It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity.
  • Granulomas with little to no caseation can be seen on histology.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary.

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few lesions which are well demarcated, annular plaques which extend centrifugally. Periphery show erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules as seen in the image below.

 

 

  •  They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face. Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar with nodules.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring & squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular drugs.

 

CLASSIFICATION OF CUTANEOUS TUBERCULOSIS IS BASED ON THE MODE OF ACQUISITION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids therapy:

  • This is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris.
  • Topical steroids are used for inflammatory conditions, and while they may reduce inflammation and symptoms temporarily, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection that causes lupus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Anti-leprosy treatment:

  • Although leprosy is also caused by a mycobacterium (Mycobacterium leprae) and anti-leprosy drugs are used to treat it, the clinical features described do not match leprosy.
  • Moreover, the treatment regimens for leprosy and tuberculosis are different.

 

Option C. Anti-fungal therapy:

  • Fungal infections can present with skin lesions, but the description of the lesion as characteristic of lupus vulgaris does not fit a fungal infection.
  • Anti-fungal therapy would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by irregular plaques that show progression at one margin and healing with scarring at another, and to understand that the appropriate treatment is a multi-drug anti-tubercular therapy regimen.

 

References:

 

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 27.21-27.23, 32.35-32.36, 33.44-33.45

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with painful oral mucosal lesions and blisters on her skin. A biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence microscopy is used to examine the skin specimen. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by painful mucosal lesions and skin blisters.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) image shows a characteristic "fishnet" or "chicken-wire" pattern due to IgG antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3, which are components of the desmosomes that connect epidermal cells.

 

The disruption of these desmosomes leads to acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation, as seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The presence of painful oral lesions further supports this diagnosis, as they are commonly seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: This condition also presents with blisters but typically in older patients without mucosal involvement. DIF shows a linear pattern of IgG and C3 at the basement membrane zone, not the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is characterized by intensely pruritic vesicles and papules, typically on extensor surfaces. DIF shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, which is different from the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Lupus vulgaris: This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting with slow-growing reddish-brown nodules, not blisters. It does not show a fishnet pattern on DIF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful oral lesions and skin blisters, and its hallmark DIF finding is the fishnet pattern due to antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

 

Explanation:

 

Leaves of broad ligament:

 

  • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include:
    • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni: Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
    • Koblet’s tubules: Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
    • Epoophoron: Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
    • Para-oophoron: Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
    • Gartner’s duct: Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.

 

Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calymmatobacterium granulomatis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium granulomatis.
  • It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Option C. Ureaplasma urealyticum: Causes urethritis

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: Causes syphilis

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mite

 

Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The primary vector for this disease is not the adult mite but its larval form, known as a chigger. Chiggers are tiny, red larval mites that transmit the bacteria to humans through their bite. The disease is also sometimes referred to as "chigger-borne rickettsiosis" due to this vector relationship.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tick: While ticks are vectors for other rickettsial diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever (caused by Rickettsia rickettsii) and Indian tick typhus (caused by Rickettsia conorii), they are not responsible for transmitting scrub typhus.

 

 

Option B. Louse: Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. They do not transmit scrub typhus.

 

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for endemic typhus caused by Rickettsia typhi. They are not associated with scrub typhus transmission.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickettsial diseases:

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Based on the clinical presentation of low hemoglobin levels, the presence of target cells in the blood smear, and the need for repeated blood transfusions, the most likely diagnosis is thalassemia. Thalassemia is an inherited disorder affecting the production of alpha- or beta-globin chains, leading to an imbalance in globin chain synthesis. This imbalance results in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, requiring frequent blood transfusions.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A genetic disorder that can be categorized into alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia based on the affected globin chain. The severity of the condition depends on the number of functioning globin genes.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive diagnosis of thalassemia is made through globin gene sequencing, which identifies mutations in the genes encoding the globin chains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): HPLC is used as a screening tool for thalassemia and other hemoglobinopathies by analyzing hemoglobin fractions. However, it is not definitive for diagnosing thalassemia.

 

Option B. Ferritin levels estimation: Ferritin levels are used to assess iron stores in the body, particularly in cases of iron deficiency anemia or iron overload. It is not diagnostic for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: While bone marrow aspiration can reveal ineffective erythropoiesis and hypercellularity, it is not used for a definitive diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Hemoglobin Patterns:

 

  • Normal Hemoglobin Pattern: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is another tool used for screening, often complemented by HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: Which enzyme is deficient in Von Gierke’s disease:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphatase

 

Explanation:

 

Von Gierke’s disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is crucial for the final step in the gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis pathways, where it catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate into glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream. Its deficiency leads to impaired glucose production and subsequent hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branching Enzyme: A deficiency in the branching enzyme is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV (Andersen’s disease), not Von Gierke’s disease. This enzyme is responsible for adding branches to the growing glycogen molecule, and its deficiency leads to abnormal glycogen structure.

 

Option C. Debranching Enzyme: A deficiency in the debranching enzyme characterizes Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (Cori’s disease), not Von Gierke’s disease. This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of glycogen, particularly in removing the branches from glycogen during glycogenolysis.

 

Option D. Myophosphorylase: Myophosphorylase deficiency is seen in Glycogen Storage Disease Type V (McArdle’s disease). This enzyme is involved in glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue, and its deficiency leads to muscle-related symptoms, especially during exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to impaired glucose production from gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, and resulting in hypoglycemia.

 

C/F of this disease includes glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic academia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 174

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text:
Which mediators involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Mast cell
  2. Histamine
  3. Neutrophils
  4. Prostaglandins
  5. Leukotrienes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, also known as immediate hypersensitivity reactions, are typically triggered by allergens and involve the rapid release of mediators from mast cells. The early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves several key mediators:

 

  • Mast cells (1): Play a central role in initiating the reaction. When IgE antibodies on the surface of mast cells bind to an allergen, the mast cells degranulate, releasing various mediators.
  • Histamine (2): One of the primary mediators released from mast cells, responsible for many of the acute symptoms of allergic reactions, such as vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • Prostaglandins (4): Specifically, Prostaglandin D2 (PGD2), is produced by mast cells and contributes to vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and increased mucus secretion.
  • Leukotrienes (5): Specifically, Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are potent mediators that cause prolonged bronchoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, and mucus production.

 

Other Option:

 

Neutrophils (3), while involved in various immune responses, are not typically considered mediators of the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity. They are more associated with later phases of inflammation or other types of immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves Mast cells, Histamine, Prostaglandins (D2) and Leukotrienes (C4 and D4).

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 377

choices.text: A – Apocrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Arrector pilorum, B – Apocrine sweat gland, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Sebaceous gland, B – Eccrine sweat gland, C – Arrector pilorum, D – Apocrine sweat gland
A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the skin appendages labeled A to D in the given histological image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

 

In the image provided, several distinct structures of the skin are labeled:

 

A (Eccrine sweat gland): Eccrine sweat glands are small, coiled glands located superficially in the dermis. They are responsible for temperature regulation through sweat secretion. In the image, A is identified as the eccrine sweat gland, which appears closer to the skin surface compared to the apocrine gland.

 

B (Arrector pilorum): This is a small muscle attached to the hair follicle known as the arrector pilorum. It is responsible for causing hair to stand up during cold or emotional stress, leading to goosebumps.

 

C (Sebaceous gland): These glands are associated with hair follicles and secrete sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. In the image, C is correctly identified as the sebaceous gland.

 

D (Apocrine sweat gland): Apocrine sweat glands are located deeper in the dermis or hypodermis and are associated with hair follicles. They produce a thicker, milky secretion that contributes to body odor when broken down by bacteria. D is correctly labeled as the apocrine sweat gland, which is found deeper compared to eccrine glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eccrine sweat glands are located closer to the skin surface, arrector pilorum is a small muscle connected to hair follicles, sebaceous glands produce sebum and are linked to hair follicles, while apocrine sweat glands are deeper and secrete a thicker fluid associated with hair follicles.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in young patients presenting with symptoms of visual field loss and a calcified suprasellar mass on imaging. This tumor's characteristic location and calcification are key diagnostic clues.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

choices.text: Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA)
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a condition commonly seen in diabetes patients with high blood sugar levels (RBS: 450 mg/dL). The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are characteristic of DKA.

 

The laboratory values indicate a metabolic acidosis:

 

  • pH of 7.34: Slightly acidic, indicating acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate of 12 mmol/L: Low, consistent with metabolic acidosis.
  • Chloride of 92 mmol/L: Lower than normal.

 

To determine the type of metabolic acidosis, we calculate the anion gap:

 

 

An anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L indicates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). In this case, the anion gap is 31, confirming HAGMA. 

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is typically associated with conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, renal failure, and ingestion of toxins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA): This occurs when the anion gap is normal (less than 12 mmol/L). Conditions that cause NAGMA include diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. This does not match the patient's high anion gap.

 

Option C. Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis: This condition involves an elevated pH with high bicarbonate levels. The patient’s pH is acidic, not alkalotic, and bicarbonate is low.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Characterized by a primary increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels leading to a low pH. The patient’s primary disturbance is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is “ boot shape heart “

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: A child is having fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What is the abnormality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Patent vitello-intestinal duct

 

The patent vitello-intestinal duct, also known as a patent omphalomesenteric duct, is an abnormality where the duct that normally connects the yolk sac to the midgut during fetal development fails to close. This duct connects the ileum to the future umbilicus, and if it remains completely patent, it can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, as seen in this case.

 

The persistence of the entire duct results in a direct communication between the ileum and the umbilicus, which can cause fecal matter to be discharged through the umbilicus. This condition is also referred to as an enterocutaneous fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalo-mesenteric cyst: This condition occurs when only a part of the vitello-intestinal duct remains patent in the middle, leading to a cystic swelling along the tract of the former duct. It does not cause fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Remnant urachus: The urachus is a remnant of the fetal connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. A patent urachus would result in urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal discharge.

 

Option D. Omphalocele:  Presents with abdominal wall defect with herniation of intestines covered by peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal discharge from the umbilicus in a child is indicative of a patent vitello-intestinal duct, which involves the persistence of the fetal duct connecting the ileum to the umbilicus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Grey

 

The patient presents with erosions on the cervix, which is indicative of cervicitis. According to the syndromic management guidelines for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), cervicitis is treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

STI color coded kits:

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of blast injuries, the liver is considered the least vulnerable to the direct effects of the blast wave due to its solid and dense nature. The primary blast wave from an explosion affects air-filled and delicate structures more significantly than dense, solid organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GI tract: The GI tract, especially the hollow parts, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage and perforation of the intestines.

 

Option B. Lungs: The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast injuries because they are air-filled and delicate. Blast waves can cause severe pulmonary barotrauma, leading to conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion.

 

Option D. Ear drum: The eardrum is extremely sensitive to the pressure changes caused by a blast wave. It is a thin membrane that can easily rupture in an explosion, making it one of the most commonly injured organs in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable organ to the primary blast wave compared to the GI tract, lungs, and eardrum, which are more susceptible due to their air-filled nature and delicate structures.

questions.text: A child presents with thinning of hair and scaling of the scalp. On taking further history, it is found that she consumes raw eggs in her diet regularly. The given manifestations are due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biotin

 

Biotin (Vitamin B7): The given clinical vignette of scaling of scalp and alopecia as well as the history of raw egg consumption suggests biotin deficiency.

 

Raw egg white contains avidin, which tightly binds to biotin and renders it unabsorbable from the intestine. Hence, there can be a biotin deficiency state. Biotin deficiency is known to cause hair thinning and scalp scaling, among other symptoms related to the skin and hair. Biotin is essential for healthy skin, hair, and nails.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition known as pellagra, which primarily presents with symptoms such as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Thinning hair and scaling of the scalp are not typical features of niacin deficiency.

 

Option B. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency can result in various neurological symptoms and skin changes, but it doesn't typically manifest as thinning hair and scaling of the scalp.

 

Option D. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it does not typically present with hair and scalp issues like thinning and scaling.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

questions.text: Most common cancer in Indian women? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

Breast cancer is currently the most common cancer among Indian women. This trend has shifted over the past decade. Previously, cervical cancer was the most prevalent, but recent data indicate that breast cancer has surpassed cervical cancer in incidence. The increased awareness, better screening programs, and lifestyle changes are contributing factors to this shift. Breast cancer is now the leading cancer affecting women in India, followed by cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical cancer: While it used to be the most common cancer in Indian women, it is now the second most common after breast cancer.

 

Option B. Endometrial cancer: This is less common compared to breast and cervical cancers in Indian women.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer has a lower incidence rate compared to breast and cervical cancers among Indian women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among Indian women, having overtaken cervical cancer in recent years.

choices.text: Loss of knee jerk
Reduced muscle tone

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulfate. What is the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of knee jerk

 

  • Therapeutic range: The therapeutic range of magnesium for the prevention of seizures in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.
  • Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of DTRs, specifically the knee jerk reflex. This occurs when plasma magnesium levels reach 7-10 mEq/L.
  • Respiratory depression: When plasma magnesium levels reach 10-12 mEq/L, respiratory depression occurs. Beyond 12 mEq/L, respiratory paralysis and respiratory arrest can occur.
  • Cardiac arrest: Cardiac arrest can happen if serum magnesium levels exceed 25 mEq/L.
  • Monitoring: A patient on magnesium sulfate is monitored for toxicity by checking clinical signs, including DTRs, urine output, and respiratory rate.
  • Treatment of toxicity: Treatment for magnesium sulfate toxicity involves administering calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (1g intravenously) and discontinuing magnesium sulfate, which usually reverses mild to moderate respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Hypotension is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: Respiratory depression occurs at higher magnesium levels (10-12 mEq/L), after the loss of knee jerk reflex.

 

Option D. Reduced muscle tone: Reduced muscle tone is not the first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity and is less specific than the loss of DTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity is the loss of deep tendon reflexes (knee jerk).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition page 759

questions.text: Which fontanelle is the last to close during normal skull development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior

 

The anterior fontanelle (Bregma) is the largest and most prominent fontanelle on a baby's skull.

 

The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

 

These openings in the skull allow for flexibility during childbirth and rapid brain growth during infancy. Fontanelles gradually close as the bones of the skull grow and fuse.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Fontanelle (Lambda):

 

  • The posterior fontanelle is located at the junction of the occipital and parietal bones of the skull. Unlike the anterior fontanelle, the posterior fontanelle is smaller and less noticeable.
  • The posterior fontanelle usually closes within the first few months of life.

 

Option C. Occipital Fontanelle (Sphenoidal):

 

  • The term "occipital fontanelle" is less commonly used, and it may refer to a small soft spot located at the back of the head, near the occipital bone. This area is generally less significant than the anterior and posterior fontanelles and closes early in infancy.

 

Option D. Mastoid Fontanelle:

 

  • The term "mastoid fontanelle" is not commonly used in the context of fontanelles on a baby's skull.
  • The mastoid region of the skull is a bony area located behind the ear, and it does not typically have a soft spot or fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region
Brilliant transillumination when a light is shone through the mass
Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the Tillaux sign? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

 

Tillaux sign is seen in presence of mesenteric cyst, which shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.

 

The Tillaux sign refers to the observation that a tumor arising from mesentry, typically a mesenteric cyst will move in a direction perpendicular to the line of mesenteric attachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region: While the presence of a mass can be indicative of many conditions, the Tillaux sign specifically refers to the mobility of a mass in relation to the mesentery attachment, not merely the presence of a mass.

 

Option B. Brilliance of transillumination when a light is shone through the mass: This describes the positive transillumination test that might be observed in cystic masses like hydroceles or  superficial cysts with clear fluid like ranula.

 

Option D. Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed: This refers to a fluctuation test, where pressing on one side of a fluid-filled mass results in a palpable bulge or movement on the opposite side. This indicates the presence of fluid within the mass but isn't related to the Tillaux sign.

 

In summary, the Tillaux sign helps in the clinical assessment of abdominal masses, with the mass's mobility providing clues about its origin and location in relation to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.

 

Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst:

 

  1. Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump
  2. Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment
  3. Zone of resonance around the lump

questions.text: Which is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium valproate

 

Sodium valproate is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea. It's an anticonvulsant medication that has proven effective in managing the involuntary movements associated with this condition. It works primarily by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which helps reduce abnormal electrical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a medication used primarily to treat gout by reducing the levels of uric acid in the blood. It is not used for the treatment of rheumatic chorea.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures. While it can provide muscle relaxation and sedation, it is not the drug of choice for managing refractory rheumatic chorea.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in some movement disorders. While it has been used in chorea, it is not considered the optimal treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its side effect profile and efficacy compared to sodium valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred drug for treating refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its efficacy in reducing involuntary movements by enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. It has a better side effect profile for long-term management of this condition compared to other options.

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). The X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

 

In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

 

Structures seen are:

 

  1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  2. Frontal sinuses
  3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth).
  4. Zygoma
  5. Zygomatic arch
  6. Nasal bone.
  7. Frontal process of maxilla
  8. Superior orbital fissure
  9. Intratemporal fossa.

 

Other 3 Options: Not best visualized in Water's view as this technique primarily highlights the maxillary and other larger sinuses.
 

Educational Objective:
 

Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the calf muscles after walking for a certain distance. The pain is relieved by rest and reoccurs upon resuming walking. Based on Boyd’s classification, what is the most likely grade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade III

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of intermittent claudication, which is pain in the muscles due to inadequate blood flow that occurs with exercise and is relieved with rest. 

 

Patient gets pain on walking, but it compelled to rest leading to relief of pain. This is the scenario in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I: This usually refers to asymptomatic or mild claudication, where the patient has noticeable pain or discomfort in the muscles but can continue to walk and pain disappears.

 

Option B. Grade II: Patient gets pain on walking, but it is bearable and can continue to walk with a limp. 

 

Option D. Grade IV: This implies pain is at rest (not included in the original Boyde’s classification).

 

Given the description of the pain being relieved by rest and reoccurring upon walking, it suggests the patient's symptoms are more than just mild claudication but have not yet progressed to rest pain, which would indicate Grade III.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The patient's symptoms of calf pain upon walking that is relieved by rest is indicative of intermittent claudication, likely corresponding to Grade III of Boyde.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotypes is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG

 

Explanation:

 

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). The pathogenesis of AIDP involves autoimmune mechanisms where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the peripheral nerves. This autoimmune response primarily involves the production of IgG antibodies against gangliosides present on the nerve membranes.

 

IgG antibodies are significant in the diagnosis and monitoring of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, and tests for ganglioside antibodies (such as anti-GM1 IgG) are commonly ordered in clinical settings to support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is primarily involved in mucosal immunity and is not a key player in the pathogenesis of AIDP.

 

Option C. IgM: Although IgM antibodies are involved in initial immune responses, they are not primarily associated with AIDP pathogenesis.

 

Option D. IgE: IgE is associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections, not with the autoimmune processes seen in AIDP.

 

Educational Objectives

 

IgG antibodies are involved in the pathogenesis of Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP), which is the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding perimortem cesarean section? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper segment cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

An upper segment cesarean section is performed during a perimortem cesarean section (PMCS). PMCS is an emergency cesarean delivery of a woman who is expected to die within the next few moments or has just died.

 

Key points about PMCS:

 

  • Timing: According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • Purpose: The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts.
  • Fetal Outcome: The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death.
  • Surgical Technique: A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed.
  • Location: PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LSCS: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not typically used in PMCS.

 

Option B. Pfannenstiel incision: This is a horizontal incision typically used in elective cesarean sections, not in emergency PMCS.

 

Option D. Done in OT: PMCS does not need to be performed in the operating theatre; it can be done immediately at the site of the patient to save time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) involves performing a classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision in an emergency situation to improve maternal and fetal outcomes.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459265/

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a patient with head trauma whose CT brain scan reveals an epidural hematoma (EDH) with mass effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) An immediate craniotomy

 

When a patient with head trauma has an epidural hematoma (EDH) with mass effect, which means significant compression, the next step in management should be an immediate craniotomy (surgical evacuation of the hematoma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observe: Observation is an option for small EDHs without mass effect, which is a rare scenario as EDHs typically result from arterial bleeding and cause significant compression.

 

Option C. IV fluids: IV fluids may be given for other purposes like hypovolemia due to bleeding but are not the appropriate management for this condition.

 

Option D. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt is performed for the condition of hydrocephalus not in the case of an EDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with head trauma and an epidural hematoma (EDH) causing mass effect (significant compression) on a CT brain scan, the next step in management is an immediate craniotomy (surgical evacuation of the hematoma) to decompress the brain.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, cardiomegaly observed on imaging, pedal edema, a gallop rhythm on cardiac auscultation, and rales in both lungs. Based on this clinical presentation, which suggests congestive heart failure (CHF), which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to prevent the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Captopril

 

The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with heart failure, as indicated by symptoms such as dyspnea on exertion, nocturnal dyspnea, cardiomegaly, pedal edema, a gallop rhythm, and rales in the lungs. All the listed drugs can be used in the management of heart failure, but the question specifically asks about preventing the progression of the disease.

 

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor, which has been shown to be effective in reducing mortality and morbidity in patients with heart failure and in preventing the progression of heart failure. It works by decreasing afterload and preload, improving symptoms, and slowing the progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is used to reduce the symptoms of fluid overload in heart failure, such as pedal edema and pulmonary congestion, but it does not have a significant impact on the progression of the disease.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that can improve symptoms and cardiac function in heart failure but has not been shown to prevent the progression of the disease and is associated with significant toxicity.

 

Option D. Carvedilol: Carvedilol is a beta-blocker that has been shown to improve survival in heart failure. However, it is generally not used as a first-line therapy for acute exacerbation due to its initial negative inotropic effect, but it can be beneficial over the long term for improving cardiac function and reducing the risk of progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, is the best choice for preventing the progression of heart failure due to its effectiveness in reducing mortality and morbidity, decreasing afterload and preload, and improving symptoms and long-term outcomes in heart failure patients.

choices.text: Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat

questions.text: What does the FDA say about a diet, high in fat intake? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Diet should contain total 1000 kcal

 

  • According to FDA, high fat diet is a diet having 50% of total caloric content of the meal and a high calorie diet is a diet containing total 1000 kcal.
  • This meal should derive approximately 150, 250, and 500-600 calories from protein, carbohydrate, and fat, respectively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates: Incorrect. While carbohydrates are a part of the diet, this specific statement does not match the FDA's guideline for a high-fat diet.

 

Option C. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat: Incorrect. A high-fat diet typically derives around 500-600 kcal from fat, not 800 kcal.

 

Option D. Diet should contain 80% fats: Incorrect. A high-fat diet is defined by having around 50% of its caloric content from fats, not 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The FDA defines a high-fat diet as one that has around 50% of its total caloric intake from fats, and a high-calorie diet should contain a total of 1000 kcal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with early satiety, bleeding and on examination, patient has spleen palpable till umbilicus. WBC count is 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs seen in the peripheral blood smear. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myeloid Leukemia

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The patient presents with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, bleeding, and a significantly elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs in the peripheral smear. These features are characteristic of CML, a type of leukemia where the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells. The presence of immature WBCs (a left shift) and massive splenomegaly are classic signs of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): While AML also involves immature WBCs, it usually presents more acutely and with less pronounced splenomegaly.

 

Diagnosed if – Myeloid blast count >20%;  APL (t15:17); CBF (t8:21; t16:16 inversion 16)

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL): CLL typically presents with a high number of mature lymphocytes rather than immature WBCs.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: This condition is unlikely in a 60-year-old due to autosplenectomy typically occurring by age 3-4, making splenomegaly in this age group highly unlikely. Moreover, the WBC count in sickle cell anemia is not usually elevated to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CML should be suspected in patients presenting with massive splenomegaly, significantly elevated WBC count, and immature WBCs on peripheral smear. Recognizing these signs can prompt further diagnostic evaluation, including the detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene).

 

CML ideally Diagnosed as – Blast count <20% + Philadelphia +ve + Left shift in PS (lots of immature WBC)

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

 

The most common fixative used in a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). This fixative helps preserve the cells collected on the slides for cytological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formalin: Formalin (10%) is commonly used as a fixative for histology specimens but is not used for Pap smears.

 

Option B. Air dried: Air drying is not a method used for preserving Pap smear specimens as it can lead to poor preservation of cellular details.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. Tissues must be immediately transferred to formol saline if using normal saline temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633
